title-group.article-title: Book Review: Night Call and Between Hours: A Collection of Poems by Psychoanalysts

author-notes.corresp: Joan Wexler 255 Bradley Street New Haven, CT 06510 E-mail: joan.wexler@yale.edu

article-meta.product: Night Call. By AblonSteven Luria . Austin, TX: Plain View Press, 2011, pp., $14.95.
Between Hours: A Collection of Poems by Psychoanalysts. Edited by AkhtarSalman . London: Karnac Books, 2012, + pp., $16.95.

body.p: Collections of poems written by psychoanalysts raise questions: what are the similarities and differences, for example, between poetry and psychoanalysis, and what distinguishes a poem written by a psychoanalyst from poems written by others?

The shared experience of the analyst and analysand is a creation unique to the particular characteristics of each person and to the present changing moment in their personal histories. The joining of a poem and a reader is also a unique mix; although the poem remains constant, the reader is not and the poet is absent. Analyst and analysand are both present, though not necessarily constant. Analyst, analysand, and reader share the experience of subjectively engaging with the voice of another. Poetry is a created product, analysis a created process.

When a poem moves a reader, he or she may experience a flow of memories and associations, feel surprise at a different view of something familiar, or feel confronted by something unexpected, strange, or disturbing—experiences familiar to the analysand. Similarly, the analysand, by his or her own words or by those of the analyst, can be startled or excited, experience a frisson or an outpouring of grief, or feel a sense of fullness—a good feed. Both analysis and poetry when they work have a powerful bodily component. Emily Dickinson captured the potential bodily power of some poetry when she wrote, “If I feel physically as if the top of my head were taken off, I know that is poetry” (Higginson 1891, p. 9).

Transferences—the presence of internalized others—are active in analysand, analyst, reader, and poet. What moves one reader may have no affect on another. A poem that leaves a reader unmoved at one time may have a powerful impact at another. While this may be true for any art form, poetry and analysis share the verbal representations of primary process—condensation, displacement, metaphor—and the music, rhythm, and meanings of language. All have the potential to quicken our senses.

Some poetry is so finely wrought and so tuned to unconscious experience it has almost universal appeal. Shakespeare’s sonnets are one rare example. More frequently a poem, or a fragment of a poem, either captures a reader’s imagination and visceral response or it doesn’t.

I tend to look for a strong sense of place in a poem. I need place as an anchor or placeholder as the poem sails off in surprising directions. Some readers may thrill to feeling lost in space or relish the challenge of abstract ideas. Place can be a landscape or an interior. Place when perceived in a poem evokes the feeling and moving body in space. Even a still life painting, by form and subject, evokes the body and its senses. As I explore the poet’s landscape I want to feel and envision the body in motion as it breaks upon the world or breaks free of it. First thrust into the world, then held and carried, our first explored landscape and sense of place was our mother’s body. The unique style of physical engagement between mother and baby inflected our explorations. Some readers may desire more holding, some more carrying, and some more physical action.
I enjoy poems that include the quotidian details of a life, including objects—the pots and pans, the shoes and socks. For me this renders the ordinary extraordinary.

A universal aspect of poetry is musicality of language. Musicality allows words to say more than their literal meaning. The music of language ties us to the primal hearing of our mother’s voice when language was only music—sounds and rhythms. In analysis, the analysand’s recumbent position, facing away from the analyst, attunes both analyst and analysand to the musical and therefore poetic aspects of spoken words.
So what of these two volumes of poetry written by psychoanalysts?

Steven Ablon’s Night Call is organized according to the unfolding of his professional life from the time of his medical training through his development as an analyst. There are three sections: “Medical School,” “Residency,” and “Practice.” In the first, “Medical School,” we meet Ablon as he first encounters and poetically captures his reactions to his patients’ exposed bodies in illness and in pain.

In “Quadruple Amputee,” Ablon must draw blood from a limbless woman and recognizes he is inflicting even more pain on her. She forgives him with a kiss, her “skin flushed with fire / forgiving fate, forgiving me.” Here is a fragment from the end of the poem.

In this gentle and detailed metaphor we experience a young medical student’s feeling and fear of his helplessness in the face of inexorable loss and frailty. Daisies will appear again in a later poem—suggesting that they represent something important for the poet. According to Wikipedia, in the “language of flowers” daisies not only signify purity and innocence; they are also durable, adaptable survivors. They can be trammeled one season and bloom the next.

I was particularly moved by “Differential Diagnosis,” another poem in this section. Ablon recognizes that his patient has all the symptoms of lupus. Urgently, in short staccato phrases, he lists the worrisome symptoms as he discovers them. Then he interrupts himself.

disp-quote.p: with crust cut off. Tip Top bread.

body.p:
He returns to observing his patient’s symptoms and sits on the edge of her bed,
precarious as a sub
of hard salami,
corned beef, sauerkraut,
Lupus on the darkest rye [p. 21].

The child-friendly soft grilled cheese sandwich on Tip Top bread can no longer comfort him. He tries to compensate. His own body sitting on the bed feels as “precarious” or dangerous as a sub(marine). He persists—hard salami, the salt of corned beef, the acid of sauerkraut—he must face it—Lupus on the darkest rye. Perhaps rye is a pun on wry—his final effort to find some mordant comfort in the presence of his patient’s suffering.

In the section “Residency,” Ablon conveys the weight of responsibility and exhaustion he feels as he cares for desperately sick people. With precision, trepidation, and a sense of awe he intrudes upon and sometimes invades the still strange landscape of his patients’ bodies. He struggles to find his compass by evoking memories of his own familiar landscapes. The effect is like hearing a precise and singable melody punctuated with the counterpoint of memory and overtones of feeling.

“Aspirating a Lung” is an example. We are privy to Ablon’s feelings while he searches for something familiar about the strangeness of his task. “The latex gloves are as dry / as a baseball mitt on opening day.” Next we briefly return with him to the present.

disp-quote.p: I line the needle up between the ribs,
like between third base and home [p. 41].

body.p: Immediately he brings us back to the present as he draws on the syringe: “the thick / effusion to be catalogued on a slide.”

disp-quote.p: I smooth the dressing, the adhesive grip
tense as the black electrical tape
compressing the neck of my bat.
Mrs. G. and I suspended here
in the dugout of her lungs [p. 41].

body.p: In the section “Practice,” Ablon is now a physician of the mind; however, the body is always present as we bear witness to his patients’ gestures, small and large. I found the most moving poem of this section to be “The Tick,” not about a patient but about his mother. Here it is in its entirety.

disp-quote.p: It is a tick rooted in the center
on her stove, walk with her
to the living room and sit
away. I pry under that tick,

body.p: The delicate and profound intimacy of the poem packs a primal punch. This poem of carefully chosen words feels ineffable and secretive. It is as though the words whisper from beneath his mother’s skin. There is violence in it—drawing the mother’s blood as though biting her breast. Although different, it drew to mind the force of John Donne’s “The Flea,” where the image of a detestable and tiny insect evokes a potent and driven libidinal world.

In Between Hours, Salman Akhtar gathers a collection of poets who are psychoanalysts. They are presented in alphabetical order, with a brief biography for each preceding their poems. Several of the poets collected here have also written articles on literature and psychoanalysis (see Akhtar 2008; Hamer 2008, 2012; Jones 1997; Richards 2000). The collection begins with Akhtar’s poems.

Ahktar writes in a variety of styles—narrative, surreal, extremely condensed. Some poems are oblique and some very direct. He embraces themes of sexual passion, nostalgia and ironic anger, the anger of feeling helpless and the anger of injustice. An example of this is in “A World without Seasons,” dedicated to Indian immigrants in the United States. Here are the final four lines.

disp-quote.p: Proudly we mispronounce our own names
And those of our monuments and our children
Forsaking the grey abodes and sunken graves of
Our ancestors, we have come to live in

body.p: Gerald Garguilo writes about loss and grief with exquisite delicacy and strength. His carefully constructed poems attend to form and music. As I reread them I found myself remembering the Cavatina from the fifth movement of Beethoven’s Quartet in B-flat op. 130, Adagio molto espressivo. Here is “The Found World” in its entirety.

disp-quote.p: We recall when first we made the
And knew it as our own.
We are a memory of light

body.p: Forrest Hamer writes and hears poems through his body. Here is “Genesis,” a poem about the poet, the poem, and the reader who re-creates them.

disp-quote.p: and each one seeks its listener out.
A poet hears first some hint,
maker, each time the poem made

body.p: Sheri Hunt, poetry editor of The American Psychoanalyst, incarnates her landscape with acuity to sound and language. She achieves this most vividly in “Green Lake.” She begins “We live by a lake, / Not dwell.” She ends more emphatically: “We live by a lake, / We do not dwell.” In the poem she brings her lake to lustful life. Here is a section.

disp-quote.p: The lake, our lake, quickens in the ready sun.
The lake’s aroused below the surface,

body.p: Her lake is aroused and her swimmers as well as they immerse themselves in its spirited waters.

Alice Jones’s poetry rings out with vibrant movement, sensuality, and the flavor of words. In “Circus” she uses the metaphor of swinging on a trapeze. With remarkable concision she captures the dizzying thrill of body and mind as the poet finds words to express it.

disp-quote.p: to find words, not a fall

body.p: Eugene Mahon, attentive to poetic form and classical themes, moves supplely from surface to depth, from past to present and back again as he captures the extremes of despair, terror, rage, and lost love. In “Dream” he uniquely captures the elusiveness and unapproachability of a dreamer dreaming.
The surprise in this poem is “When words split / The dream in two.” Split has a force that asserts the poet’s urgency to find entry into the mind of the dreamer. Words are the tool.

Rebecca Meredith writes narrative poems that capture a primal, sensual sense of the Mississippi Gulf Coast in dazzling detail—speech, gesture, and steamy soporific heat—all undercoated with serious humor and the urgently needed, soul-saving power of the blues. The following fragment is from “Intergenerational Delta Blues,” in which Meredith returns to her place of birth “to watch my father die.” She brings her son with her. It is his first trip to the place of his mother’s origins. Here is a segment.

disp-quote.p: That’s the way it is, I told him,
the radio plays country and evangelicals, and nothing else.
The cell phones don’t work at all.
And all you can do is lay yourself on
the delta’s dinner table and let the kudzu take you;
cuss you for a Yankee dog
and submit to it until you can run, still living, away
and just let it have the dead [p. 65].

body.p: I cannot leave Merideth’s poems without mentioning “When Old, Old Women Up and Get The Blues.” A pelvic throbbing blues beat speaks as much as the words to capture the heartache and the still pulsing heart of being “old, old” and alone. Here is the opening segment.

disp-quote.p: When old, old women up and get the blues,
they dream a dream that slowly, gently creeps
around their lonely thighs and collar bones—
and when those middle nights deny them sleep
it leaves them, makes them moan and toss and weep [p. 72].

body.p: Arlene Richards’s colorful poetry surprises with Chagall-like magical realism, unexpected objects, and wild movement. The moods of her poems vary, expressing sadness, tenderness, lust, and fear. Most address someone—lover, mother, father, an old man on the bus. “Halloween” captures her voice.

disp-quote.p: Your ghost ate chocolates and refused to ski.
Mine drank music and wore boots.
Yours loved to shop, to throw furious pots.
Mine finally removed his red toupee.
Our ghosts dance on the shaggy green rug,
We’ll fold their sheets, top and bottom,

body.p: Arnold Richards’s elegiac poems offer biographies and histories of family, friends, and acquaintances in a few condensed lines. Here is a section from “Father’s Day.”

disp-quote.p: My father had a stubble beard
a crippled gait, a sad face, a quiet voice
My father had a troubled life.
A world destroyed, A god that failed [p. 88].

body.p: Elise Sanders writes dream and memory poems rich with quotidian details that capture an aching heart. Here is a fragment from “Old House.” The poet wanders through her now empty house.

disp-quote.p: If I wander there, my heart beats so heavy I have to lie
down on the hard floor of sorrow.
my emotional hands with dreams of ever after,
the table is no longer here, its surface sticky with flecks of glitter
and stray sharpie marks bled through a project [p. 95].

body.p: In his prologue to this volume, Akhtar tells us about poetry as a bridge that links the unknown and the known, the preverbal and the verbal, music and prose, male and female, emotion and logic, merger and separation, reality and unreality. Poetry, he says, “is not located midway between reality and unreality but simultaneously accommodates both of them. It is both subjective and objective” (p. xiv). He ends the volume with an epilogue about the interplay between psychoanalysis and poetry: “In the end it is all about transformation through listening. Writing poetry requires listening to one’s own self and conducting psychotherapy requires listening to the Other. Both endeavors transport the inner and incomprehensible baggage of the heart to the outer and comprehensible platform of the mind” (p. 106).

So what distinguishes these poems as poems specifically by psychoanalysts? Attention to detail, a nonlinear sense of time, the past as it lives in the present, how the infant alive within us never truly sleeps, the unexpected—all these are elements both of fine poetry and of psychoanalysis. I cannot distinguish the fine poems in these collections as specifically by psychoanalysts. These are poems by poets. I commend both volumes without reservation.
